p: To address climate change mitigation for air travel, a growing body of literature considers its disproportionate impact (Brand and Boardman, 2008). There is an attitude and behavioral gap when it comes to individual considerations for air travel (Bel & Rosell, 2017). Even people who are concerned about climate change appear unwilling to change their travel behavior or purchase offsets, developing rationalizations to justify their own air travel (Brouwer, Brander, & Van Beukering, 2008). Air travelers cite professional development (Wynes & Donner, 2018), positive social benefits from experiencing new cultures, and leisure benefits as reasons for continued flight (Becken, 2007), which are all personal, as opposed to collective, reasons that lead to unwillingness to compromise air travel (Boucher, 2017).
